A quick point to our honourable member: eight years ago the Labor Party was in government, six years ago the Labor Party was in government, five years ago the Labor Party was in government and four years ago they were in government. Quite obviously, these jobs have been going for a long time and they need better representation.

speech.para: I want to bring to the House the news that a world record was broken not so long ago which went basically unmentioned throughout the world, including in Australia. A local man by the name of Gary Parsons completed the 10,000-kilometre continuous long run around Australia. He broke the record on the South Australian border by 27 days. He averaged 74 kilometres a day continuously for 156 days and he was continuing to run for another 10,000 kilometres. I drove from Adelaide to the South Australian border to run with him for about five kilometres and bring to him a thousand good wishes from the school children of the Caboolture region.

The great thing about this man and his wife is that he is running for Legacy. He left on Anzac Day from Brisbane and we hope that he will return there with the world long run record of about 20,000 kilometres in another three months time. He is now through Adelaide. He will be going through Tasmania and then back up along the east coast. I think he is going around Tasmania three times. At the time our troops were not deployed.

The great thing about running for Legacy is that Legacy continues to grow as a need in this nation and will continue to grow to 2007. The work that Gary has done, the knowledge that he has brought to the Australian public right around this great nation of ours about the fine work of Legacy, and the money raised by the generosity of people as they have passed him by on his long haul, dropping money into the can, are all most welcome. I congratulate him on his world record and wish him the best as he heads towards 20,000 kilometres and another fine world record for Australia.

talk.start.para: —Before calling the next speaker, I do want to make it quite clear to the Committee that, by the convention which is observed, the call goes from one side to the other. In the event that two people jump up and one has already spoken, regardless of which side that member is on, the call must go to the member who has not spoken.

—I want to take this opportunity to highlight to the parliament a growing trend over recent decades for people to work harder, longer and generally come under more pressure from work commitments. There is countless anecdotal evidence of this situation. People are always saying that they work more hours now than years ago. They are also working on weekends and working more unsociable hours. What was once work outside normal hours, or overtime, has now become the norm. There is great pressure to conform to longer working hours or weekend work purely because everyone else does it. It is a vicious circle. The longer we work, the more is expected, and the hours that used to be considered extra are now considered standard.

speech.para: There is also some very accurate data to back this up. From 1979 to 1998, those working standard hours fell from 65 per cent to 48 per cent, while those working long hours rose slightly from 18 per cent to 22 per cent, and those working very long hours rose from 18 per cent to over 32 per cent. I believe this trend is having a profound impact on society, family and health.

The nature of work has changed. The concepts of full-time, part-time, casual and shift work and the definition of the working week have all changed. It is now quite common for the working week to start at any day during the week and quite common for people to work 12 hours through shift work. The impact on workers is less leisure time, family time, and time for mixing with friends and pursuing personal interests.

Decades ago technology was said to revolutionise work and make life easier. We would have machines that would do the repetitive tasks, offices that would become paperless with better communications and we could keep in touch more often. But the reality is that for many technology has become the master rather than the slave. Technological change has been a major contributor to the change in work and to longer hours. With this change has also come a need for higher education levels and more training requirements. What was once the norm of getting a job, learning the ropes and then mastering a trade, has become much more complex. Young people today must achieve year 12 then move on to higher education and continue to train and then retrain, and this is just to keep up with industry and technology or just to give themselves a decent opportunity to actually become employable.

There is also a new peer pressure in workplaces, particularly in the professional fields, to be at work longer regardless of the actual work requirement. It is almost unheard of that a manager would start at nine and finish by, say, five. Somebody working those sorts of hours would be considered lazy or just not dedicated to the job. For other workers, unpaid overtime and flexible work arrangements have been growing problems. Statistics show that increasing amounts of overtime are now unpaid and the expectation is that workers must give more of their time but they must also do it free. This trend, I believe, is so entrenched in some industries that it is now considered normal. Workers have also lost out in new flexible work arrangements, where flexibility really means longer hours, weekend work, more shifts and so on.

But among the issues that concern me the most are the personal cost to workers, the cost to the community, and the cost to our health system. I have dug up an article, a special report on work and family, from the Australian Financial Review of September 17 this year. It says:
Worker's compensation payments for mental problems, largely stress-related, run at more than $200 million per annum across Australia.
This is from the CEO of VicHealth.

Total monetary costs to the nation are estimated at three to six times this figure, in addition to the human dimensions of suffering and loss. And it's going up sharply. In Western Australia, the rate almost doubled between 1988 and 1994. In Victoria, stress payments rose from $14 million to $54 million between 1986 and 1993.
Stress is the end result of a number of factors including increased workload, increased hours, decreased resources, decreased autonomy and uncertainty.

Nonetheless, according to a recent Japanese study, hours spent at work have a direct bearing on health. It found that men who worked 11 hours a day had around 2.5 times greater risk of heart attack than men working an eight hour day.
And again, as the article said:
Workers compensation payments . . . at more than $200 million per annum across Australia . . .

It is timely that I am actually speaking on this issue, given that yesterday in the House we debated the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 . This bill is an absolute joke. The title is a joke but the irony, I am sure, is not lost on anyone. The title of the bill should really read, `Some jobs perhaps, more hours, but definitely less pay.' This is where this bill will take workers in the future. Instead of addressing the issues of increasing work to benefit workers and industry, it is aimed directly at reducing the rights of workers. More consideration should be given to the issue of work practice and the implications that it has for our society. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Recently, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs informed the 90 staff in Raymond Street, Bankstown, at the Bankstown Department of Immigration, that they would no longer be required in Bankstown as of February next year when the lease runs out. Those 90 staff cover about 25 people in the counter staff area—citizenship, and other associated areas—where there is heavy client contact. There are also people from the compliance group who have a New South Wales-wide activity, though most of their compliance work takes place in Sydney. They have been told that they will keep their jobs but they will move to either the central business district or Parramatta.

speech.para: We have already seen lots of job losses in the City of Bankstown since I was elected on 15 June 1996. This government has taken more than 440 jobs from the Bankstown tax office and moved those to Hurstville and Parramatta. There are still 220 people in the Meredith Street building of the Australian Taxation Office, and it seems they will be there until 2002 when the lease runs out on that.

When I spoke to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs he informed me about this and that the staff were going to be told that they would be moved. I made the point to him, in conjunction with Daryl Melham, the member for Banks, and also Laurie Ferguson, the member for Reid, that this employment in Bankstown is important to the local economy and the life of the people in Bankstown. The employment of people and having the office open is important to all the clients, in one of the most diverse areas in Australia, who have access to and use the Bankstown office of Immigration. Taking that away, moving people back to effectively a centralised approach to immigration service delivery, directly has a cost to all of those people, who either have to travel to Parramatta or travel into the city.

The further point I made was that this is going back to the bad old days that we had with the tax office when it was in Hunter Street and with the Immigration office only at Chifley Square. We had a regionalisation program. All that is left of it after this decision, if they go ahead with it, is an office in Rockdale adjacent to the airport, an office in Parramatta and an office in the central business district, dealing primarily with business migration issues. But the people who have to access those services, and there are so many in the electorates of Blaxland, Reid and Banks, will be grossly disadvantaged, as will the local economy of the area.

We have made an offer for the department to look at the Bankstown council building, which has been vacated by two state departments, and to look for a long-term lease within that building. I have also pointed out to the minister, so that he could point out to the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance and the Prime Minister, that the Bankstown taxation office has $22 million worth of dead Commonwealth money being spent on it up to 2002. There are three to four floors of that building entirely naked of any occupants. For the last two years they have tried to sublet it and they cannot. The 220 people there in the superannuation section cannot move to Hurstville or Parramatta because they do not have any more room in the tax offices there. So the impact on Bankstown is a loss of almost 100 other people. That takes the all-up figure to well over 530 people who used to work for the Commonwealth in the area and who will not be there.

The key ability that was there in the regionalisation program of allowing people to work near where they live, to be part of the community that they are providing services for, to know that community better, to understand them and therefore to be able to better provide those services, has all been lost. That is to the detriment of the Commonwealth employees, of the people who are there as their clients and customers and of the total city of Bankstown.

On top of this, as Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl well knows, for the seventh time, the regionalisation of aircraft into a dedicated airport at Bankstown would inexorably lead to the loss of up to 3,500 existing general aviation jobs at Bankstown airport and having those displaced out of Bankstown. I think that, inexorably, a hubbing of regional aircraft would mean that there would be nothing left in their place. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to relate a very pleasant encounter last Saturday when I was a guest of the Carnarvon Pistol Club in Western Australia. I would particularly like to record my thanks and congratulations to the president of that club, Lou Puccinelli.

speech.para: Pistol shooting is not something that I would normally engage in, but through contacts with this club some months ago I invited myself along to this statewide event that attracted 52 shooters from as far afield as Perth and Karratha. It was most impressive. The thing that I believe needs to be recorded is the exceptionally high degree of concern for safety in this particular sport. In fact, the statistics quite clearly indicate that you are at more risk on roads in Australia than you are in the vicinity of a particular pistol club range.

The pursuit for this two-day event was practical pistol, which involves some 2,500 members Australia-wide today. It replicates a situation that is to be unfortunately found in real life today and that is the rescue of hostages from a real-life drama. It is a growing sport and, even though many would look upon it with disdain as perhaps dramatising some of the unfortunate aspects of life, it is a sport that requires constant dedication and a high degree of athleticism, accuracy and speed. But underlying all of the disciplines of this particular sport is the demand for safety. Every shooting situation requires a fully qualified and experienced range officer in attendance and at all stages of the competition range officers control every action.

Except under the control of a range officer, participants of the club taking part in the shoot are not at any stage allowed to take a pistol out of a holster, at no stage is even an unloaded pistol allowed to be cocked, and ammunition is at all times kept separate from pistols. A pistol is only loaded, cocked and fired under the direct control of a range officer. There are stringent controls about the firearm, at all times, being pointed down range or at no more than 90 degrees left or right from down range. I was, as you may get the impression, exceptionally impressed by the high degree of safety and the very stringent controls placed upon that.

Shooters that might travel, in this case, some thousand kilometres to participate are sent home at the say-so of the range officer for any breach of rules. His participation in that particular competition and his presence at great expense are cancelled immediately with any contravention of the safety rules. The day that I was able to witness was a huge success, demanding a high degree of competition. It was rounded off by a very successful dinner provided by the very capable wives of the participants, and they put on a marvellous spread. It was a community effort and a thoroughly enjoyable day was spent there. I once again congratulate Lou and the club for informing me just so much more as to how safe guns can be when handled correctly.

subdebateinfo.title: UNESCO Draft Convention of the Protection of Underwater Cultural Heritage
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 833)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 August 1999:

question.para: (1) What were the (a) names, (b) positions and (c) qualifications of the persons who represented Australia at the second meeting of governmental experts preparing the draft Convention on the Protection of Underwater Cultural Heritage (Paris, 19—24 April 1999).
(2) What international bodies and other countries were represented at the meeting.
(3) What is the timetable for adoption and ratification of the Convention.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) At the second meeting of governmental experts to consider the Draft Convention on the Protection of Underwater Cultural Heritage (Paris, 19-24 April 1999), Australia was represented by:
Mr Matthew Peek, Permanent Delegate to UNESCO
Mr Arthur Spyrou, Deputy Permanent Delegate to UNESCO
Dr Claus Dirnberger, First Secretary, Australian Embassy, Bonn
Ms Kirsti Samuels, Adviser, Permanent Delegation to UNESCO
Mr Graeme Henderson, Director, Western Australian Maritime Museum
(2) The following Member States of UNESCO were in attendance:

Algeria, Argentina, Australia, Austria, Barbados, Belgium, Belize, Benin, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Brazil, Cambodia, Cameroon, Canada, Chile, China, Columbia, Costa Rica, Cote d'Ivoire, Cuba, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, Ethiopia, Finland, France, Gabon, Germany, Ghana, Greece, Grenada, Guinea-Bissau, Haiti, Honduras, India, Indonesia, Iraq, Iran, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Jamaica, Japan, Republic of Korea, Madagascar, Malawi, Malaysia, Malta, Mexico, Namibia, The Netherlands, Nicaragua, Nigeria, Norway, Oman, Pakistan, Peru, Philip pines, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russian Federation, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent & The Grenadines, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Syria, Tanzania, Togo, Tunisia, Turkey, Uganda, Ukraine, United Kingdom, Uruguay, Venezuela.
The following Associate Members of UNESCO were in attendance:
The Holy See, Palestine, United States of America.
The following intergovernmental organisations were in attendance:
United Nations, International Seabed Authority.

(3) There is, as yet, no timetable for adoption and ratification of the Convention given that states are still some way from achieving a final text. The April 1999 meeting agreed that negotiations would continue in 2000, but did not set a date when they would take place.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 August 1999:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No 448 (Hansard , 11 May 1999, page 5103), what percentage of over the water flights could be achieved by utilising a combination of mode 4 and mode 2 of the long term operating plan.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Airservices Australia has advised that using a combination of Mode 2 and Mode 4 is unlikely to increase the percentage of over the water flights. This is because both modes have the same projected availability due to wind. Additionally Mode 2 involves landings over Kurnell Village and departures overflying residential areas of Sutherland. Avoidance of departures overflying Sutherland would require reduced lateral separation and the likely increased weather minima that would then apply would reduce the availability of the mode.

subdebateinfo.title: National Health and Medical Research Council: Research Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 889)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 26 August 1999:

question.para: What portion of the funding to the National Health and Medical Research Council is allocated to (a) hepatitis C and (b) HIV research.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) Funding allocation to hepatitis C research in 1999 totals $290 000, representing 0.2 per cent of the total National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) funding in 1999. Some hepatitis C research is included in the HIV/AIDS figure but it is not possible to identify specific amounts; and (b) a total of $5.194 million has been allocated to HIV/AIDS research in 1999, $4.64 million being provided by Australian National Council on AIDS and Related Diseases (ANCARD). This represents 3.13 per cent of the total research funds administered by the NHMRC.
